entry.title: Reusable APIs in SAP Integration Suite : Design Once, Use Everywhere
entry.content:
Introduction

Reusable API  artifacts in SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Edge Integration Cell are modular, internal-only APIs that encapsulate common cross-cutting concerns such as authentication, transformation, validation, or logging.

Instead of duplicating the same policies across multiple APIs, Reusable API act as centrally managed building blocks that can be invoked by other API artifacts through  a special API Direct adapter.

 Key characteristics:

Internal only: They are not exposed as standalone endpoints.

Policy encapsulation: Common logic like authentication or schema validation is defined once and reused.

Independent lifecycle: They can evolve separately from consuming APIs, supporting cleaner governance and versioning.

Performance-aware: Optimized for low-latency chaining between calling APIs and Reusable API s, with correlation IDs ensuring full traceability.

Consistency & compliance: Authentication policy is enforced uniformly across the execution chain.

Use Cases it Addresses

Reusable API artifacts address several real-world challenges faced by API developers and central security/governance teams:

üîëCentralized Security Enforcement

Instead of configuring authentication and authorization separately in every API, organizations can define a Reusable API  artifact with standard security policies (e.g., OAuth/JWT verification, API key validation, IP allowlist). Any new API simply invokes this artifact, ensuring compliance with enterprise-wide standards and reducing the risk of inconsistent security coverage.

‚öôÔ∏èPolicy Reuse & Reduced Duplication

Enterprises often repeat the same transformations (e.g., XML-to-JSON), validations (e.g., schema checks), or response formatting across multiple APIs. By centralizing these policies into Reusable API  artifacts, teams avoid duplication, simplify maintenance, and accelerate delivery of new APIs.

üìäAuditability & Governance

With traceability built in via correlation IDs, Reusable API  artifacts give central teams visibility into how APIs interact across the execution chain. This is particularly useful in regulated industries where demonstrating uniform enforcement of policies (like logging or data masking) is mandatory.

üöÄAccelerated API Development

Developers can focus on business-specific logic in their APIs while leveraging pre-built Reusable API  artifacts for cross-cutting concerns. This speeds up delivery, ensures consistency, and lowers onboarding time for new API projects.

 Creating and consuming a Reusable API Artifact

   Prerequisites
  • Enable API Management and Cloud Integration capabilities  and 
  • Provision Edge Integration Cell runtime.

After you have setup Edge Integration Cell and enabled both the capabilities mentioned above, you will have option to create API artifact. 

         In a typical organization, two key personas benefit the most from reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite:

  1. Central Security Administrator ‚Äì responsible for defining and enforcing security standards across all exposed APIs. They ensure consistent authentication, authorization, and compliance policies without duplicating effort.
  2. API Developer ‚Äì responsible for designing APIs in Integration Suite, modelling business logic, and creating proxies for backend services. With reusable APIs, they can focus on business functionality while relying on centrally managed security and governance.

Lets create a Reusable API as security administrator persona :

 A security administrator logs in to the Integration Suite tenant and navigates to Design ‚Üí Integrations and APIs, then selects an existing content package to model a Reusable API.

              

Select the Edge Integration Cell runtime profile and proceed to choose the API creation method. Among the four available options, you will notice a new entry: Reusable API.

 

 

Provide the required API details to create a Reusable API .

 

Important to note: A Reusable API artifact does not require a target URL or a virtual host since it is designed for internal invocation only via a calling API  using the API Direct adapter. Therefore, it does not have an externally invokable endpoint.

Once all the details are provided, click on Create to create a Reusable API .

 

The sender adapter in a Reusable API is automatically set to API Direct. This is important because it allows the calling API artifact to invoke the Reusable API internally‚Äîwithout an HTTP endpoint and without external exposure. Now, let‚Äôs add a few security policies like Authentication and Authorization to it.

 

 

 

In addition to security policies, you can add mediation policies to extend functionality. For example:

  • Use a Content Modifier to enrich or adjust the message payload.
  • Configure an External Callout to log data to external services such as Loggly.

With these steps, we‚Äôve modelled a Reusable API that handles authentication and authorization, while also logging transaction details to an external system.

Consuming the Reusable API

Let‚Äôs model a caller API that proxies an external backend while consuming the Reusable API created in the previous steps.

Provide the mandatory details for the caller API.

For a standard API, an Authentication policy is always applied as the first policy by default. However, when consuming a Reusable API that already includes an authentication policy, you should remove the default authentication policy from your calling API. This ensures there‚Äôs no duplication or conflict.

As a boundary condition: The first step in your calling API must be either Authentication policy or a Reusable API with Authentication policy as its first step. This keeps the flow clean, avoids redundant auth checks, and maintains proper execution order.

Now, let‚Äôs add a step to invoke the Reusable API created earlier. As the first step, add the reusable API artifact as a global reference in your caller API, as shown below. 

The Reference dialog will display only the deployed Reusable APIs within a package. If you need to reference multiple reusable APIs, you can add them from different content packages simultaneously.

To consume the reusable API, add a Request-Reply step along with a Receiver System to invoke the reusable API. From the list of adapters, select API Direct only. Since the reusable API already includes an Authentication policy, go ahead and delete the authentication policy from your calling API to avoid duplication.

 

Let‚Äôs click on API Direct to configure the adapter‚Äôs connection details, which enables us to reference the reusable API added earlier as a global reference in this API.

 

Now, let‚Äôs examine the properties associated with the API Direct adapter in detail.

 

 a) Resource :This allows you to associate any added reusable API as a reference to this API.  

 b) Address :A read-only field that displays the basepath of the reusable API added in the Resource section. 

 c) Send Body  :Check this box to send the original request body to the reusable API. This is typically used with   POST, PUT, or PATCH methods, where the request payload must be preserved and forwarded to the reusable     flow. 

 d) Retain Original Body for Next Steps : Select this option to keep the original request body available for use in subsequent steps of your caller API.

 e) Headers

  • Request Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers (e.g., Authorization|X-Correlation-ID) to send to the reusable API.
    Use * to send all headers by default.
  • Response Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers from the reusable API‚Äôs response that should be merged into the caller API‚Äôs original request headers.
    Use * to receive and merge all response headers by default.

Now we have modelled and consumed a Reusable API into the caller API. Please note that if the Reusable API is not deployed, then you will not be allowed to deploy the caller API referring that Reusable API . Now let‚Äôs deploy the caller API.

As both caller and Reusable APIs are deployed, Lets check the status and also invoke the caller.

Monitor and Message logs

Once APIs are deployed lets navigate to Monitor section to introspect the both Caller and the Reusable APIs under Manage Integration Content.

 

One important point to note about reusable APIs is that, since they don‚Äôt have an external endpoint, the Endpoints section does not display any entry as shown above.

 Let change the log level to Trace for both the artifacts.

Now let me invoke the caller API endpoint via a REST client.

 

Let‚Äôs now check the correlation ID for this transaction in both the caller and reusable API logs ‚Äî they should ideally be the same, ensuring end-to-end traceability.

As you can see, the API was invoked successfully.

If you recall from earlier steps, we modelled the reusable API to provide Authentication & Authorization protection and included a mediation policy to log the correlation ID to the Loggly server.

As you can see, the same correlation ID is also being logged into the Loggly server.
Additionally, you can examine the trace details of the executed steps, which will show that the first step was executed via API Direct, exactly as we modelled in our use case.

 

Similarly, the same Reusable API is referred  to another API artifact by the API developer to leverage the centrally defined security and common tasks by administrator.

If a new traffic management policy like Surge protection policy is to be added to all the APIs then API administrator only needs to it to the Reusable API and it will be automatically applied to all the APIs referring the Reusable API.

Points to remember:

  1. At least one authentication policy is mandatory in complete chain including the caller API and Reusable API.
  2. Only Authentication policy or a request reply step to Reusable API can be added as first step in a valid caller API.
  3. A caller API can refer more than one Reusable API, but one Reusable API cannot refer another Reusable API.
  4. Only deployed reusable APIs can be added to the caller API.

Summary

Reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite bring clarity and efficiency to API management. By separating centralized enforcement from API development activities, organizations can achieve both governance and agility. The administrator gains confidence that policies are consistently applied, while the API developer can focus on delivering business value without reinventing the wheel for every project.

In short, reusable APIs strike the right balance between control and productivity, making them a cornerstone for scalable, enterprise-grade API strategies.

entry.title: Everything you need to move to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction - Why Now Is the Moment to Modernize Your SAP Integrations

Digital leaders are defined by the ease with which they connect people, data and processes. Yet many SAP customers still rely on SAP Process Integration/Process Orchestration (PI/PO) or SAP Cloud Integration (Neo environment)‚Äî platforms that have served well for years but were designed for a very different era of IT.

Today‚Äôs reality is hybrid and multi-cloud. Applications span on-premise data centres, hyperscalers and SaaS solutions; business models evolve in weeks, not years; and customers expect real-time, event-driven experiences. In this landscape, integration is no longer a back-office utility‚Äîit is the strategic backbone that powers innovation, agility and growth.

SAP Integration Suite is SAP‚Äôs answer to this new paradigm: a modern, enterprise-grade iPaaS that unifies API-led, event-driven and process integrations under one roof. With 200-plus connectors, AI-assisted tooling, and flexible deployment options across any major cloud, it‚Äôs purpose-built to help you:

  • Retire technical debt by moving from aging middleware to a future-proof platform.
  • Accelerate time-to-value with pre-packaged integration content and proven migration tools.
  • Operate hybrid at scale‚Äîbridge on-premise systems with cloud applications seamlessly.

This blog series is a practical guide for two key audiences:

  1. PI/PO customers planning a phased or full migration from on-premise middleware to the cloud.
  2. Neo-CPI customers ready to transition their integrations to the Cloud Foundry‚Äìbased SAP Integration Suite.

We offer a guided approach to holistic integration that allows you to map your own unique journey by:

  • Assess your integration strategy while defining requirements
  • Leverage proven patterns for various integration scenarios and environments
  • Define integration best practices by adopting expert recommendations
  • Gain insights and adopt agile integration practices for continuous improvement

We‚Äôll walk through preparation, tooling, migration steps, and best practices‚Äîbacked by screenshots, tips from the product team, and lessons learned from early adopters. Whether you‚Äôre charting your first pilot or orchestrating an enterprise-wide move, you‚Äôll find everything you need to modernise with confidence and speed.

Let‚Äôs get started.

 

  1. Connect SAP and Third-Party Systems Efficiently

Whether you're connecting SAP systems or integrating with third-party applications, SAP Integration Suite provides a comprehensive, enterprise-grade integration platform as a service (iPaaS). It supports application-to-application, business-to-business, and even business-to-government integrations using modern technologies like advanced API management. With prepackaged integrations, connectors, AI-powered tools, and business-centric APIs, you can get started quickly and scale integrations seamlessly ‚Äî all while reducing manual effort and boosting efficiency.

 

  1. Accelerate Connectivity from Day One

Time-to-value is everything. SAP Integration Suite empowers you to kickstart your integration projects immediately. Thanks to its extensive library of prebuilt content, AI-supported advisors, and easily discoverable data semantics, you can reduce setup time dramatically and focus on what matters most: delivering business value.

 

  1. Enable Real-Time Business Interactions

In today‚Äôs digital landscape, real-time responsiveness is critical. SAP Integration Suite enables API-first and event-driven architectures that allow you to publish, consume, and process business data and events in real time ‚Äî both within your organization and across your broader ecosystem. This means you can power real-time insights, automation, and digital experiences that drive meaningful outcomes.

 

  1. Integrate Hybrid and Multi-Cloud Landscapes Flexibly

Modern IT landscapes are hybrid and diverse. SAP Integration Suite is designed to operate across both on-premise and cloud environments. Whether you're working in a single public cloud, multiple clouds, or a mix of on-prem and cloud, SAP Integration Suite has the flexibility to adapt. It supports deployment on major public cloud infrastructures and offers runtime flexibility, so you can execute integrations where it makes the most sense for your business.

 

  1. Migrate with Confidence

Moving away from legacy systems doesn‚Äôt have to be risky or disruptive. SAP Integration Suite offers a clear, guided path to modern integration ‚Äî supported by proven methodologies, helpful assets, and robust tools from SAP and its partners. This means you can migrate confidently, streamline operations, and unlock the full potential of your digital transformation initiatives.

Why move to SAP Integration Suite
As a technical developer responsible for SAP PI/PO, you‚Äôre increasingly constrained by its aging, on-premise architecture and the effort required to support modern, agile, and scalable integration patterns. SAP Integration Suite offers a future-ready platform that enables you to:

  • Modernize integration landscapes with cloud-native, microservice-based tools
  • Accelerate time-to-value through hundreds of pre-built integrations, APIs, and templates
  • Support hybrid and multi-cloud strategies with out-of-the-box connectors for SAP and non-SAP workloads
  • Embrace API-first and event-driven approaches for real-time responsiveness, reduced coupling, and easier extensibility

 

 Introductory Assets

Why do I need this assets?

Article: Producing tangible business benefits from modern iPaaS solutions by MIT Technology Review

Website: Smoothly transition to the cloud from SAP Process Orchestration

These introductory assets discuss why modern iPaaS solutions, like SAP Integration Suite, offer significant business benefits by streamlining and accelerating application integration through pre-built connectors, automation, and AI-enabled features for tasks like code analysis and testing, ultimately facilitating a smooth, strategic transition from legacy systems like SAP Process Orchestration while boosting agility and efficiency.

Technical Documentation

Why do I need this assets?

Migration Guide for SAP Process Orchestration

Integration Flow Design Guidelines

The technical documentation guides users through migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, covering assessment, migration steps, and best practices for designing integration flows in the new cloud-based environment, with a focus on connectivity, security, and error handling.

 Blogpost

Why do I need this assets?

Elevate from SAP Process Orchestration and Modernize your integration platform with SAP Integration Suite

Accelerate move to SAP Integration Suite with SAP Integration Suite Testing Service

These blog posts provide information about the strategic imperative and practical aspects of migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite. They discuss the use of automated testing and migration tools to accelerate the transition, minimize risks, and ensure a smooth go-live.

Devtoberfest Sessions

Why do I need this assets?

Migrating to SAP Integration Suite with Int4 Shield

Successfully plan, prepare and execute your migration to SAP Integration Suite with Figaf

Partner Webinars:  https://events.sap.com/modernizationjourneywithpartners/en_us/home.html

 

These sessions focus on how to successfully plan, prepare, and execute a migration from SAP Process Orchestration, emphasizing the critical role of automated testing and migration tools like Int4 Shield and Figaf to reduce complexity, risk, and manual effort.

 Tutorials from SAP Tutorial Navigator

Why do I need this assets?

Use the Migration Assessment Application

How to migrate RFC Lookups from SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration

Learn how to migrate JDBC Lookups from SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration

Learn how to migrate SFTP Advanced File Selection from SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration

These tutorials collectively teach how to leverage the Migration Assessment Application to plan and execute the migration of various integration scenarios (specifically RFC Lookups, JDBC Lookups, and SFTP Advanced File Selection) from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Cloud Integration, including practical steps and considerations for each type of migration.

 Learning Journey

Why do I need this assets?

Migrating to SAP Integration Suite


Developing with SAP Integration Suite

 

The learning journeys equip integration designers and developers with the knowledge and skills to successfully migrate integration scenarios from legacy SAP Process Orchestration/Process Integration to the modern SAP Integration Suite.

 Discovery Center Mission

Why do I need this assets?

Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite

Automate the Migration from SAP Process Integration to SAP Integration Suite with Figaf 

These missions include best practices and step-by-step guidance for use case implementation, supported by mission experts and SAP Community.

 

Why move to SAP Integration Suite
As a technical developer using SAP CPI on the Neo environment, you face architectural and operational limitations that hinder modern integration demands. With SAP‚Äôs strategic shift to the Cloud Foundry-based SAP Integration Suite, now is the time to evolve and future-proof your integration capabilities:

  • Leverage a modern, flexible runtime based on Cloud Foundry with greater scalability and resilience
  • Access the full capabilities of SAP Integration Suite, including enhanced API management, event mesh, and open connectors
  • Simplify operations with improved lifecycle management, monitoring, and DevOps-friendly tooling
  • Adopt hybrid integration strategies with support for cloud, on-premise, and third-party systems

 

Introductory Assets

Why do I need this assets?

Free assessment for SAP BTP, Neo environment

 

Access this free service to assess your current SAP BTP, Neo environment implementation; plan your migration to the multicloud environment; and develop a migration plan.

Technical Documentation

Why do I need this assets?

SAP Cloud Integration Migration Guide

Use this guide to transfer your integration scenarios in the Cloud Integration tenant from the Neo environment to SAP Integration Suite in the Multi-Cloud Foundation.

Blogpost

Why do I need this assets?

Migrate from Neo to Cloud Foundry - SAP Cloud Integration

This blog highlights the process with some screen shots of migrating integrations from a Neo tenant to Cloud Foundry tenant

 Learning Journey

Why do I need this assets?

 

Modernizing Integration with SAP Integration Suite

This course offers a concise yet comprehensive introduction to SAP Integration Suite, covering the key capabilities, the importance of a defined enterprise-wide integration strategy, and how you can leverage AI to modernize your business landscape.

 

Thank you very much for tuning into the blogpost. We hope that those assets will help you to accelerate your journey to the next-gen integration platform SAP Integration Suite. Plese keep in mind that moving from PI/PO or Neo-CPI is not simply a ,,lift & shift" but it is a journey to a modern way to connect business processes and applications across your enterprise.

Big thanks to Kristin McMahon and Ryan Champlin for co-authoring this blogpost!

entry.title: Lessons Learned: Fetching Learning History from SuccessFactors LMS Using OData APIs
entry.content:
Introduction

When integrating SAP SuccessFactors LMS (Learning Management System) with downstream systems, one common requirement is to extract Learning History data ‚Äî i.e., the courses a user has completed.

In this blogpost, I‚Äôll share my journey of exploring the OData V4 APIs provided by SuccessFactors LMS, the challenges I faced, and how I managed to make it work with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI).

This article is especially useful if you are:

  • Trying to pull learning history records from LMS

  • Wondering why your API calls return errors like ‚Äúmissing search criteria filter information‚Äù

  • Looking for ready-to-use Groovy code to loop through users in CPI

Exploring the LMS OData V4 APIs

The base metadata endpoint looks like this:

https://<tenant>.lms.hr.cloud.sap/learning/odatav4/public/user/userlearning-service/v1/$metadata

From the metadata, we can see entity sets like LearningHistories and learninghistorys.

üëâ A valid API call to fetch a user‚Äôs learning history looks like this:

GET https://<tenant>.lms.hr.cloud.sap/learning/odatav4/public/user/learningHistory/v1/learninghistorys?
$filter=criteria/targetUserID eq 'STUDENT001'

And the response returns details such as:

  • componentID ‚Üí Course ID

  • title ‚Üí Course Title

  • completionDate ‚Üí Date Completed

  • status ‚Üí Completion Status

Challenges I Faced

During implementation, several challenges came up:

  1. Malformed URI errors ‚Äî caused by wrong resource paths in the CPI SuccessFactors adapter.

  2. 404 Not Found ‚Äî when calling invalid entity sets (e.g., /LearningEvent is not supported in V4).

  3. ‚ÄúMissing search criteria filter information‚Äù ‚Äî occurs if you don‚Äôt pass criteria/targetUserID.

  4. Single-user limitation ‚Äî the API requires a targetUserID for every call, so bulk retrieval is not supported directly.

These were showstoppers until we aligned on the correct way to filter.

Solution: Fetching Learning History

‚úÖ The working query pattern is:

/learning/odatav4/public/user/learningHistory/v1/learninghistorys?
$filter=criteria/targetUserID eq 'STUDENT001'

This means:

  • We must pass a user ID (student ID) every time.

  • To fetch data for multiple users, we need to loop through the list of student IDs.

Building It in SAP CPI

Here‚Äôs how you can design the iFlow:

  1. Get list of users ‚Äì call /Students API or have a predefined list.

  2. Loop through users ‚Äì in CPI, use a Splitter or Groovy script.

  3. Call LearningHistory API ‚Äì pass each student ID dynamically.

  4. Collect responses ‚Äì aggregate all learning history data.

  5. Filter & send downstream ‚Äì only send completed courses or specific items (e.g., MAIR Code of Conduct).

Groovy Snippet: Looping Through Student IDs

Here‚Äôs a ready-to-use script you can copy-paste into CPI.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.*
import java.net.*
import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets

Message processData(Message message) {

    // 1. List of Student IDs (replace with dynamic input if needed)
    def studentIds = ["STUDENT001", "STUDENT002", "STUDENT003"]

    // 2. LMS LearningHistory API base URL
    def baseUrl = "https://<yourtenant>.lms.hr.cloud.sap/learning/odatav4/public/user/learningHistory/v1/learninghistorys"

    // 3. Get OAuth token from exchange property (set earlier in the flow)
    def accessToken = message.getProperty("OAuthToken")
    if (!accessToken) {
        throw new Exception("OAuth token not found. Please configure security flow correctly.")
    }

    def results = []

    studentIds.each { studentId ->
        try {
            // Build URL with criteria filter
            def query = "?$filter=" + URLEncoder.encode("criteria/targetUserID eq '${studentId}'", StandardCharsets.UTF_8.toString())
            def url = new URL(baseUrl + query)

            def connection = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection()
            connection.setRequestMethod("GET")
            connection.setRequestProperty("Authorization", "Bearer " + accessToken)
            connection.setRequestProperty("Accept", "application/json")

            def responseText = connection.inputStream.getText("UTF-8")
            def responseJson = new JsonSlurper().parseText(responseText)

            results.add([studentId: studentId, records: responseJson.value])

            connection.disconnect()
        } catch (Exception e) {
            results.add([studentId: studentId, error: e.message])
        }
    }

    // Return consolidated result
    message.setBody(JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(results)))
    return message
}

‚úÖ Example Output

 

[
  {
    "studentId": "STUDENT001",
    "records": [
      { "componentID": "COURSE101", "title": "Data Privacy", "status": "Complete" }
    ]
  },
  {
    "studentId": "STUDENT002",
    "records": []
  }
]

Key Learnings

  • The LearningHistory API works only when you pass criteria/targetUserID.

  • Bulk extraction is not supported directly ‚Äî looping is required.

  • You can optimize with CPI Splitter/Multicast for larger user volumes.

  • Always check the $metadata endpoint to confirm entity names before calling.

References That Helped

  1. SuccessFactors Integrations Beginner‚Äôs Guide: Exploring Learning Management
    (Official SAP blogpost explaining LMS OData services in detail)

  2. How to Integrate SuccessFactors LMS Module using Oracle Integration Cloud
    (A community blog showing similar challenges when integrating LMS APIs with another middleware)

These reinforced the idea that while LMS OData APIs are powerful, they also come with design constraints that integrators must handle.

Conclusion

Fetching Learning History from SuccessFactors LMS is possible via OData APIs, but you need to understand the mandatory filter requirements and handle the per-user limitation with looping.

With the right design in SAP CPI ‚Äî and a bit of Groovy scripting ‚Äî you can build a robust integration that delivers exactly what business needs.

entry.title: Local OData API Access in Edge Integration Cell Runtimes
entry.content:
Introduction

With the usage of Edge Integration Cell runtime, a mixture of Cloud and On-Prem solutions is utilized in some aspects. One of these aspects is calling the monitoring APIs. When the clients try to make such API calls in the Edge Integration Cell runtimes, their queries are bypassing the cloud to reach the corresponding edge cluster, which is done through the Web UI. Hence, there is no possibility to directly access to the APIs without the Web UI. As long as the connectivity to the cloud is available, these scenarios will work properly. However, in case the cloud connection is broken, the clients will not be able to use such functionalities and consequently will not be able to monitor their edge runtime properly. 

To tackle the above problem, a new feature is added to the cloud integration for the edge-enabled runtimes by which the clients are able to call a subset of monitoring APIs without the intervention of cloud, so called "Local API Access". This feature is available starting with Cloud Integration software version 6.71.x

In this Blog I will try to address this topic and how can this feature be used by the clients properly. We will see how can we configure the edge clusters to enable the Local Access(API Plan). I will also provide the information on how the APIs can be called and finally will provide a list of the APIs which are currently exposed locally. 

 

Configure Cluster to Support API Plan

The first step for using Local API Access, is activating the API Plan support to the cluster. This can be done using the ELMO UI. By selecting the desired cluster and modify the configuration, you will see the new settings available also for the API Plan: API Virtual Host and API Virtual Host Key Alias. These settings are also available upon on-boarding of a new edge node. This is also depicted in the following picture. 

  • API Virtual Host can be any preferred valid domain name of your choice. In case this is supposed to be exposed to internet, then this also needs to be registered in the DNS as well. 
  • API Virtual Host Key Alias is similar to what you have in the default virtual host. This is the alias of keystore entry which contains a valid key and is stored on the corresponding edge runtime. 

 

Configuring API Plan Support in ELMO UI

 

Once these settings are applied, the corresponding new resources will be created in the K8s cluster including a new Gateway which is created for directly accessing the APIs. The Edge runtime will now be able to handle local API calls. 

 

Required Authentication Setups for calling APIs

At the time of writing this Blog and in the initial increment of this feature only the certificate-based authentication is supported for local API Accesses. As the clients are making calls against the new API Virtual Host directly and this is handled by HTTPS connectivity, an MTLS connectivity is required to be established to the cluster. The clients are required to provide the public and private keys for a TLS Connection. The required service key(needed for the public and private keys) can be achieved using the BTP Account Cockpit in cloud integration. You need to create(or use the existing one) a new API Service instance for accessing APIs as followed

  • Service: Process Integration Runtime 
  • Plan: Process Integration API access

Service Instance Creation for API Plan

 

 

You then need to create a new service key (or use the existing one) in the above Service Instance using the Certificate client type. Once this is created successfully use the created credentials for the TLS connection. You can use the certificate chain as well as the key entry which are provided there in the newly created credential.

Creating new Certificate Key for API Plan Service Instance

Accessing Certificate and Private Key for calling Local APIs

 You need to consider that accessing certain APIs requires also special permissions(Roles) and for having proper access to the APIs you need to assign all the required Roles to your service instance at the time of creation too. 

You can use the certificates and key in the above in order to establish a TLS connection to your cluster and calling the desired API with your favorite REST Client. For simplicity, you can also keep the above data in two different files and simply refer to them in your REST Clients e.g. Curl.

 

Calling the APIs 

So far, we have seen how to activate the API plan on the edge runtimes and also how to properly setup the required athentication parameters to make the API Calls. We are now good to see how the actual API call works. For this, you need add a /local prefix to your defined Virtual Host followed by /ap1/v1/<Desired Endpoint>. Adding the /local prefix here is important, as this will be used to distinguish the local API calls from the calls via cloud. If you do not use the /local prefix then a 401 Unauthorized error would be thrown, even if you use a valid credential. 

Here is an example of the API Call: https://<YOUR_DEFINED_VIRTUAL_HOST>/local/api/v1/<DESIRED_ENDPOINT_TO_BE_CALLED>

  • <YOUR_DEFINED_VIRTUAL_HOST>: This is the Virtual Host that you have defined for your your edge Runtime in ELMO UI
  • /local: This prefix is required to be added to the endpoint call in order to distinguish the local calls from the calls via cloud
  • /api/v1: Conventially used for calling APIs, similar to the calls over the cloud
  • /<DESIRED_ENDPOINT_TO_BE_CALLED>: The desired endpoint which is supposed to be called. This is similar to the calls over cloud.
    • e.g. MessageProcessingLogs

As mentioned earlier, for the initial increment of this feature only a subset of the APIs are exposed for local access, here is the list these APIs:

  • /MessageProcessingLogs
    • Including sub-entities 
      • /MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations
      • /MessageProcessingLogAttachments
      • /MessageProcessingLogCustomHeaderProperties
  • /MessageStoreEntries
    • Including sub-entities 
      • /MessageStoreEntryProperties
      • /MessageStoreEntryAttachments
      • /MessageStoreEntryAttachmentProperties
  • /DataStores
    • Including sub-entities 
      • /DataStoreEntries
  • /JmsBrokers
  • /Variables

The complete definition and usage of the APIs is defined in the official SAP API documentation page . The usage of the APIs should be adapted according to the above explanations for the local accesses. Please consider that the APIs are only exposed for the Monitoring purposes. This means, that only Get REST API calls are allowed to be done locally and none of the other methods would be available.

entry.title: Migrating from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite (CPI): A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

As organizations move towards cloud-based integration platforms, migrating from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite (CPI) becomes essential. This blog will walk you through the key steps of this migration, focusing on:

  • Connecting SAP PO to SAP Cloud Connector And adding SAP PO in SAP Integration Suite (CPI)

  • Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO

  • Importing dependent objects of the Message Mapping,  such as Imported Archives and Function Libraries

 

‚Äå‚Äå Step 1: Connecting SAP PO to Cloud Connector

Since SAP PO is an on-premise system, we use SAP Cloud Connector to securely connect SAP CPI (cloud) to the SAP PO environment. The Cloud Connector acts as a secure tunnel between cloud applications and on-premise systems without exposing them directly to the internet.

  1. Install SAP Cloud Connector  on the same network as SAP PO (for testing install on your system).

  2. Connect Cloud Connector to your SAP BTP subaccount (SAP CPI tenant).
    Establishing a Connection Between Cloud Connector and Subaccount 

  3. Login to the SAP Cloud Connector and select the subaccount and click on Cloud to On-Premises.

  4. Add the SAP PO System in Cloud Connector.

    Back-end Type: ABAP System
    Protocol: HTTP
    Internal Host: *PO Sytem Host Name without http://*
    Internal Port: *PO Sytem port*
    Virtual Host: *Enter a desired virtual hostname. This will be used when connecting from Integration suite.*
    Virtual Port: *Enter a desired port*
    Allow Principal Propagation: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Principal Type:Kerberos
    Host in Request Header: Use Virtual Host
    Next ==> Next==>
    Check Internal Host: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Finish

     

  5. Add resources path by clicking on the + icon and enter / select Path and all Sub-Paths ==> Save.

  6.  Check whether the added SAP PO system is reachable.

    If it's not, cross-check the host and port. Ensure that both the SAP PO system and the Cloud Connector are accessible through the same network.

  7.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from SAP Cloud Connector.

Step 2: Connecting SAP PO  to SAP Integration Suite(CPI) Through SAP Cloud Connector

 

  1. Login to the Integration suite, Go to settings ==> Integrations==> select System Tab==> click on +  to add the SAP PO Sytem.

  2. Enter the details of System Overview and Integration Directory.

    In the Address box, enter the Virtual Host and Port with http://, as maintained in the Cloud Connector.
    If your PO System uses the same address for both the Integration Directory and the ES Repository, check the corresponding checkbox‚úîÔ∏è. Otherwise, specify them separately. 
  3. Test the connectivity between Integration suite and SAP PO system.

  4.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from Integration suite.

Step 3: Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO to SAP CPI

  1.  Login to the Integration suite and go to your package and click on Add message mapping. Selcet ES Repository and select the added SAP PO System and connect.

  2.  Select the required message mapping and click on next.

  3.   To import Message mappings there are some prerequisites:

    Based on your message mapping, you may have dependent resources such as a Function Library, Imported Archive, WSDL, or XSD. 

    WSDL and XSD files are imported automatically along with the message mapping. However, Function Libraries and Imported Archives must be imported separately.

    After selecting the message mapping, you will be able to see the list of dependent resources. You must import the required resources (Function Library and Imported Archive) first; otherwise, the message mapping cannot be imported successfully.

     

 

  1. Importing Dependent Objects: Function Libraries
    1. Create a function library artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your function libraries, save, and then deploy.

    2.  Create a Imported Archives artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your Imported Archives, save, and then deploy.

           4. Since the dependent objects have been imported, we can now import the message mapping. Add the message                               mapping artifact, select the ES Repository, choose the added SAP PO system, connect, select the message mapping,                     click "Next," and then select the dependent objects that were imported as separate artifacts.

5. Click on "Select" and choose the required function library artifact.

6. If the status shows "Already Existing," click on it and select "Reuse Existing Resource.

 

7. Next, click on "Select" and choose the required imported archive artifact. Then, click "Submit" to import the message      mapping.

 8.  Now the Message Mapping is successfully imported to Integration suite from SAP PO system.

 

Conclusion

Migrating from SAP PO to SAP CPI goes beyond a simple technical shift‚Äîit‚Äôs an opportunity to modernize integration landscapes, adopt cloud-first patterns, and leverage the flexibility of SAP BTP. By carefully setting up connectivity through the Cloud Connector, systematically migrating message mappings, and addressing dependencies like archives and function libraries, you can ensure a smooth and reliable transition.

A phased migration approach, combined with thorough testing and best practices, will help minimize risk and maximize value. This journey not only preserves existing investments but also sets the stage for future-ready integrations.

Stay tuned for my upcoming blogs, where I‚Äôll deep dive into adapter migration strategies and lessons learned from real project experiences. üöÄ

entry.title: Integration Advisor: complex mapping code for dimension conversion in SAP B2B
entry.content:
Introduction

In many B2B integration scenarios, it‚Äôs common to encounter values that must be converted depending on a specific dimension‚Äîsuch as weight, length, volume, or even currency. Each of these dimensions can have multiple possible units, and the integration process must ensure that the target payload uses the correct unit and precision.

For instance, this article uses a weight conversion example involving kilograms (KGM), grams (GRM), and decigrams (DG). However, similar challenges arise with other measurements, eg. centimeters vs. meters, liters vs. milliliters, or different currency codes with varying decimal rules. Without proper handling, these mismatches can cause data errors, disrupt downstream processes, and lead to costly corrections.

At present, the Integration Advisor‚Äôs Mapping Guideline (MAG) does not include built-in functions for this type of unit-based calculation with dynamic precision control. However such functionality can be implemented by applying an XSLT transformation MAGs.

In this blog, we will explore an XSLT-based approach using the KGM/GRM/DG case as an example and the same pattern can be adapted to many other dimensions in B2B integration scenarios.

Example: Mapping Quantity with UnitCode from EDIFACT to SAP SOAP

Let¬¥s assume that a trading partner X sends an UN/EDIFACT D.10B Purchase orders to my company, and we want to receive OrderRequest as an SOAP message.

In the source message, the data element ‚Äú6060‚Äù quantity and ‚Äú6411‚Äù measurement unit code in the segment ‚ÄúQTY‚Äù. And the data element ‚ÄúunitCode‚Äù unitCode and ‚ÄúCONTENT‚Äù quantity in the segment ‚ÄúRequestedQuantity‚Äù of the target message.

 

We assume that my company expects the quantity with the unit KGM, therefore in order to handle a mapping from source path /ORDERS/SG29/QTY where the data element 6063 equals KGM/GRM/DG, to target path /OrderRequest/Order/OrderItem/RequestedQuantity with the attribute unitCode="KGM", we will need the following steps.

  • In the target MIG(Message Implementation Guidelines), select and assign Codelist to the unitCode. Then qualifer the segment ‚ÄúRequestedQuantity‚Äù with KGM.

 

  • In the Shared Code of MAG(Mapping Guidelines), input the following xslt code with the name fx_sumOfDimensionValues_in_KGM. Then it is possible to assign this shared code into mapping function for the quantity mapping.
<xsl:variable name="vFraction" select="'4'" />
<xsl:variable name="vFraString"
    select="string-join(for $i in 1 to xs:integer($vFraction) return '0', '')" />
<xsl:variable name="vSum" select="
  if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'GRM') then 
    xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060) div 1000)
  else if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'DG') then 
    xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060) div 100)
  else if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'KGM') then xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060))
  else sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060)
"/>
<xsl:value-of select="format-number($vSum, concat('#0.', $vFraString))" />

This snippet first defines a variable $vFraction to control the decimal precision dynamically. In this case, the value is set to 4, meaning that the final output will always display up to four decimal places. The second variable, $vFraString, creates a string of zeros corresponding to the precision length, which is later used by the format-number() function to ensure consistent formatting.

The heart of the logic is in the $vSum variable. Here, we inspect the unit code from the source element D_6411 and apply the appropriate conversion:

  • GRM ‚Üí KGM: Divide by 1,000 (grams to kilograms)
  • DG ‚Üí KGM: Divide by 100 (decigrams to kilograms)
  • KGM ‚Üí KGM: No conversion needed, the value is used as-is
  • Fallback: If the unit code does not match any of the above, the raw value is used without conversion

Finally, format-number() applies the desired precision formatting by combining #0. with the zero string generated earlier. This ensures that regardless of the original format, the resulting value in the target XML will adhere to a consistent numeric pattern‚Äîessential for downstream systems that rely on strict schema validation.

 

Adapting the Pattern for Other Dimensions

Although this example focuses on weight conversion, the same approach can be applied to other measurable dimensions. For example:

  • Length: mm ‚Üî cm ‚Üî m
  • Volume: ml ‚Üî L ‚Üî m¬≥
  • Currency: adjusting for minor units (e.g., cents vs. yen)
  • Custom Units: industry-specific codes with defined conversion ratios

The main changes involve:

  1. Adjusting the if/else if logic to account for the specific unit codes you expect in the source.
  2. Modifying the conversion factor according to the required unit transformation.
  3. Setting $vFraction to match the level of precision required by your target system.

 

Summary

By embedding this logic directly into the MAG‚Äôs XSLT, you gain:

  • Dynamic Unit Handling: No need to pre-normalize values outside the integration flow.
  • Precision Control: Flexible decimal formatting without post-processing.
  • Reusability: The pattern can be packaged as a reusable function and applied across multiple mappings.

This approach ensures your integration not only transforms the data structure but also intelligently adapts values, reducing manual intervention and preventing costly data mismatches.

entry.title: Migration Journey from MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite (CI)
entry.content:
Introduction: This blog is for architect/developer navigating the migration journey. The decision of migration for any client's landscape can be for either or all of the below reasons -

  • Consolidation of multiple middleware solutions into one, to simplify customer‚Äôs landscape
  • Reduction of operational complexity
  • Reduction of operations and maintenance cost
  • Seamless integration with other SAP cloud services

Getting Started: it be helpful to train/ramp up your team to be cross-skilled in integration space. Below materials will assist to keep learning in track - 

Simplify API Design, implementation, deployment, and operation | MuleSoft Developers | MuleSoft Developers

Self-paced: Anypoint Platform Development Fundamentals (DEX401) Trailmix |

Instructor-led: https://trailheadacademy.salesforce.com/classes/DEX401-mulesoft-development-fundamentals

DataWeave: DataWeave Interactive Learning Environment | MuleSoft Developers

The key phases of any migration project includes -

Assessment - Discovery phase 

  • Inventory existing Interface related assets from MuleSoft : Interface technical documentation including architectural design decision documents, Mapping details, Sample Request/Response, Payloads, GIT Repository or JAR file to import into Any point studio for reference, APIs, RAML specs, connectors, orchestration flows.

  • Identify external dependencies: Third party systems, Salesforce, SAP, databases, and external APIs.

  • Evaluate complexity: choice routers, scatter-gather, retries, batch jobs, JMS, security policies.

  • Define KPIs (performance, SLAs, error handling) to be preserved.

Implementation - Development phase

  • Leverage SAP APIM by re-platforming API : 
    • MuleSoft RAML ‚Üí SAP APIM (OpenAPI / OData) 
    • Security policies (OAuth, JWT, client ID enforcement) ‚Üí SAP API Management policies.

 

  • Focus on reusability and error handling : 
    • MuleSoft Global Error Handler  ‚Üí CPI Exception Subprocess + Groovy retry logic + Capture Camel Exception
    • Common Data Weave Transformations  ‚Üí Groovy Script Libraries
    • Externalized configs (MuleSoft property files) ‚Üí CPI Externalized Parameters / Secure Store/ Security Material
    • Logging -> MuleSoft Custom loggers with searchable text log message ‚Üí Custom Headers + Content Modifiers

 

  • Integration flow (Pallet functions/Adapter) Mapping : Below is the mapping based on my experience in project of both middleware and now migration. Disclaimer : This is not approved design mapping by either SAP or MuleSoft. 

 

CategoryMuleSoft (Any point Studio)SAP IS (Integration Suite)Developer Notes / Migration Tips
Conditional RoutingChoiceRouterBoth route messages based on conditions. MuleSoft uses DataWeave expressions; CPI uses XPath/JSONPath/property.
Parallel ProcessingScatter-GatherMulticast + GatherMuleSoft Scatter-Gather auto-aggregates. CPI requires explicit Gather step.
Looping / IterationFor EachLooping Process CallMuleSoft inline array loop; CPI uses Local Integration Process (heavier).
Error HandlingOn Error Continue / PropagateException Subprocess (Local/Global)MuleSoft inline error blocks are cleaner. CPI requires modeling exception subprocesses.
Retry / ReliabilityUntil SuccessfulNo direct equivalent ‚Üí use Exception Subprocess with retry counter, JMS-based retry, or Groovy retry loopMuleSoft has built-in retry (configurable attempts, delay, backoff). CPI needs manual design.
TransformationTransform Message (DataWeave)Message Mapping / Groovy ScriptData Weave is compact scripting language. CPI often requires Groovy coding for advanced mapping.
Message EnrichmentEnricherContent EnricherBoth inject additional data into message. Straightforward migration.
LoggingLoggerMessage Log / Groovy log.infoMuleSoft logger is simple. CPI logging often needs Groovy for rich debug.
Reusable FlowsFlow ReferenceProcessDirect AdapterMuleSoft calls other flows inline. CPI uses ProcessDirect to call child iFlows/LIPs. Ensure property/header passing.
External CallsHTTP, Database, JMS, Salesforce, SAP connectorsHTTP, OData, SOAP, SFTP, JMS, SAP IDoc/BAPI adaptersMuleSoft has breadth of connectors. CPI focusses on depth for SAP-specific protocols.
AggregationAggregatorGatherMuleSoft allows custom aggregation strategies. CPI offers fixed patterns (post-processing in Groovy if needed).
Splitting MessagesDataWeave + For EachSplitterMuleSoft: split array in DataWeave + iterate. CPI has explicit Splitter step (XPath/JSONPath).
Variable HandlingSet Variable / PropertyContent Modifier (Header/Property/Body tabs)MuleSoft separates variables, CPI consolidates into Content Modifier.
Scheduling / PollingSchedulerTimerBoth provide cron-like scheduling.
File/Batch HandlingBatch Job (Batch Step, Commit, Aggregator)Splitter + Gather / Looping LIPMuleSoft batch module is dedicated. CPI requires modeling Splitter + Looping as per use case.

Validation - Testing phase

  • Migration validation: Compare MuleSoft v/s SAP IS outputs for same payloads. This can be achieved by running the interface in both middleware for comparison. Alternatively, the payload structure and data fields can be validated with the assistance of Functionals and MuleSoft developer. 

  • Tools & Accelerators : Do explore tools available to avoid manual validation such as INT4, Figaf.  

  • Performance benchmarking: Focus on TPS, latency, retry success rates. This needs to be monitored on application level , in-coherence to any feedback or issues reported by the business users or functional users. 

  • Security and compliance validation (GDPR, audit logs) : as part of Lift and Shift migration, the strategy should remain same; although in other cases, there should be a deep dive conversation and approval in sync with Enterprise architecture aligning to organization current integration strategy. 

Challenges and Lessons Learned from Migration Project : 

  • Transformation Logic: DataWeave scripts can be deeply nested. Converting them to Groovy requires strict null-safe functions (safeVal) and structure preservation.

  • Retry & Resiliency: MuleSoft retries are implicit; in CPI, retries must be scripted or handled via JMS/Event Mesh.

  • Monitoring: MuleSoft Anypoint Monitoring is developer friendly, where logger text can be searchable makes debugging and traceability easier.  With implementation of SAP Cloud ALM / SAP Integration Suite can provide comprehensible monitoring dashboards. In general, developers can use application message id along with correlation id for high-complex interface.

  • Governance: Ensure API versioning, lifecycle management, and documentation are preserved during migration. MuleSoft follows C4E standards, GIT repositories, however with SAP the design guideline, naming convention is client landscape specific.

  • Don‚Äôt lift and shift blindly: re-evaluate design patterns, redundant logic while migration.

  • Centralize error handling: CPI‚Äôs Exception Subprocesses combined with Groovy logging scripts give better transparency.

  • Invest in automation. tools and enable cross-skilling:  Explore tools and accelerators in market. Get Team's resource cross skilled by training or self-paced courses. Create reusable script templates (safeVal functions, header/property converters, retry utilities) for reuse across Integration flows.

  • Phased rollout: Start with low-complexity flows (point-to-point APIs) before tackling heavy orchestration jobs.

Conclusion : 

Migrating from MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite is not just a technical re-platforming  - it‚Äôs an opportunity to simplify, optimize, and future-proof your integration landscape and prepare cross-skilled teams in integration domain. 

As architects, we must balance strategic goals (cost, simplification, SAP-native integration) with technical execution (pattern mapping, resiliency, monitoring).

entry.title: Blueprints for Success: Landscape setup recommendations for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs fast-changing times, integration is not just a technical requirement but a business imperative. Organizations worldwide run on a combination of on-premises systems, cloud applications, and home-grown or partner platforms, which makes realizing efficient End-to-End (E2E) business processes that much more challenging! Integration plays a crucial role in driving digital transformation and agile innovation by enabling seamless connectivity between various systems and applications within an organization‚Äôs IT landscape.

SAP Integration Suite offers an intelligent, future-proof, scalable, AI-driven Integration Platform-as-a-Service (iPaaS) that simplifies enterprise-wide connectivity to any application or business partner, enables real-time data exchange, and supports modern integration patterns ‚Äî empowering customers on their journey towards an agile SAP Business Suite.

Every enterprise begins its integration journey with the right intentions: connecting systems, enabling business process automation, and improving agility, among others. However, without a well-defined integration setup strategy, the journey can quickly spiral into chaos.

Integration Blueprints and why they matter

Having the right integration setup is crucial for ensuring efficiency, reliability, security compliance, and resilience. A well-structured integration landscape provides the flexibility required to adapt business processes and adopt new technologies like Artificial Intelligence, forming the foundation for data-driven decision-making and business innovation.

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, an integration blueprint is a recommended landscape design that defines how integration tenants are provisioned, distributed, and interconnected to deliver enterprise-wide integration. It establishes the guardrails for security, lifecycle management, and governance across the landscape. By mapping out business processes and compliance requirements in advance, the blueprint ensures that integration projects can scale reliably while staying aligned with business goals and IT strategy.

In this blog, let‚Äôs explore how your integration blueprints can evolve from modest beginnings towards a mature, enterprise-grade landscape with SAP Integration Suite.

Evolution of Integration Blueprints

For the sake of illustration, we will follow the evolutionary timeline of SAP Integration Suite blueprints, with a fictional company, BestRun Corporation.

BestRun Corporation is a multinational enterprise operating across industries like manufacturing, retail, and financial services. Its SAP landscape is a mix of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and several custom-built applications spread across regions.

Like many organizations we work with, BestRun‚Äôs integration journey didn‚Äôt start with a big bang; it evolved.

Stage 1: The Primitive Era ‚Äì Experimentation

In the early days, BestRun Financial Services unit began with a single SAP Integration Suite tenant for a proof-of-concept. During the pilot phase, development, testing, and production all happened in the same tenant.

Although this worked well for experimentation and helped in keeping service costs low, when a bug in a test integration flow disrupted real purchase orders, they soon realized that the setup lacked critical capabilities to run their business, like workload isolation. Additionally, the setup was not meeting the BestRun Corporation company-wide compliance and audit requirements.

Pros:

  • Quick and cost-effective option to get started.
  • Simple setup, minimal management overhead.
  • Good for PoC/Pilots or experimentation.

Cons:

  • No isolation of workloads; high risk of disruptions.
  • No governance, poor compliance, and auditability.
  • Not fit for enterprise businesses.

BestRun worked with SAP to understand that once a project gets into active development or productive phase, it is strongly recommended to establish the typical enterprise setup of SAP Integration Suite, with a Multitenant landscape model to ensure separation of concerns and smooth operations.

Stage 2: The Growth Era ‚Äì Staged Development blueprint

Realizing the risks, the BestRun Financial Services team adopted a staged development setup with multiple tenants. This landscape setup follows a structured progression of controlled tenants to ensure reliable delivery of integrations, enforcing strong governance and minimal risk of impacting business operations.

A staged development setup typically consists of a 3-stage landscape, 

  • Development (Dev) tenant - where integration developers build and configure integrations
  • Testing/Quality Assurance (Test/QA) tenant - where functional validation, regression testing, and user acceptance are conducted, ensuring quality compliance, and
  • Production (Prod) tenant ‚Äì where end users consume integrations in business-critical processes, shielded from disruptions

If you only use pre-packaged integration content, then the Test/QA tenant can be used to preview and validate the content before deploying to the Prod tenant. For custom integration content development, the integration is developed in the Dev, validated in QA, and pushed to Prod.

Sometimes, additional stages like Pre-Production (Pre-Prod) and/or Staging are introduced. The Pre-prod mirrors the production environment and can be used for backups, regression testing, and delayed software updates. A Staging tenant can be set up for performance testing or a production-like validation.

Additionally, the BestRun Financial Services team wanted to run a few business-critical scenarios, which consume resources in an isolated SAP Integration Suite tenant, to ensure there are no disruptions due to resource competition. This is currently achieved using a manual Tenant-Split process, where a hand-picked integrations are moved to a dedicated tenant. However, there are investments to support such requirements seamlessly, soon.  

Staged development setup with LoBs

Usually, a staged development setup for SAP Integration Suite is tightly coupled and aligned with a staged LoB application landscape like the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL setup, where each S/4HANA Cloud tenant (DEV/QAS/PRD) is connected to a corresponding SAP Integration Suite tenant (Dev/QA/Prod) to ensure environment parity.

A similar landscape setup can also be used by SAP NetWeaver Process Integration / Process Orchestration (PI/PO) customers who typically use a 3 PI/PO system landscape on-premises. While migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite, customers need to move from a system-centric to a tenant-centric model; however, the principle remains the same.

Note that in the case of SAP PI/PO, where infrastructure is fully managed by customers, there may be instances where PI/PO systems have been set up with substantial resources. Since SAP Integration Suite operates as a cloud-based service, careful tenant sizing is recommended rather than employing a direct 1:1 mapping between systems and tenants.

Pros:

  • Clear separation of concerns and environments (Dev, Test, Prod).
  • Reduced production risk from developments, experiments.
  • Aligns with standard SAP application landscapes (e.g., S/4HANA 3SL).
  • Establishes a foundation for enterprise governance.

Cons:

  • Maybe limited to large organizations with multiple BUs or regions.
  • Requires process discipline across teams, which takes time.

In this blueprint, it will be important for BestRun to invest in a robust framework of versioned artifacts, aligned DevOps pipelines, synchronized transport management, and a strict governance setup to manage APIs & endpoints in each stage, for seamless business operations.

Stage 3: The Scale Era ‚Äì Business Entity Blueprint

With the Financial Services team recognizing business value with SAP Integration Suite, BestRun decided to expand the rollout of SAP Integration Suite to further business units like Retail, Manufacturing, etc.

Today, BestRun Corporation runs a federated IT environment, establishing logical or physical separation of IT systems within each business unit (BU) or entity, thereby enhancing compliance alignment and supporting a greater degree of autonomy. Typically, this federated approach is supported by an independent IT team dedicated to each respective business unit or entity. From an Integration perspective, the respective BU IT team will manage and maintain the corresponding SAP Integration Suite setup as well.

In such cases, it is widely regarded as best practice to provision a dedicated Integration Suite staged landscape (at least Dev -> Test -> Prod) for every business unit or entity. This arrangement enables BU IT teams to develop, test, run, and manage integrations tailored to their specific compliance obligations or organizational policies. Example:

  • Retail IT teams can focus on point-of-sale and customer loyalty integrations.
  • Manufacturing IT teams can optimize supply chain processes.
  • Finance IT teams focus on compliance-heavy reporting integrations and so on.

Pros:

  • Increase autonomy for each business unit (BU).
  • Tailored compliance alignment per BU.
  • Independent BU IT teams innovate at their own pace.
  • Reduces bottlenecks and dependency on centralized IT.

 Cons:

  • Requires investments into additional tenants.
  • Strong governance is necessary to avoid duplication of efforts and the risk of siloed BU integrations.

Stage 4: The Global Era ‚Äì Regional Blueprint

With operations in Europe, the US, and APJ, BestRun Corporation faced new challenges to meet GDPR and local banking laws, which required regional data residency, establishing distributed resilience for business continuity, and meeting LoB application performance requirements.

For multinational companies, like BestRun, with globally distributed business entities and subsidiaries, it may be necessary to deploy IT systems, including Integration Suite tenants, across multiple regions to address

  • Region-specific data residency requirements, such as GDPR, HIPAA, and local banking regulations
  • Latency requirements with Line-of-Business applications operating worldwide
  • Business continuity objectives.

This approach will enable business entities within a region to maintain a comprehensive regional autonomy, ensuring data residency and adherence to region- and industry-specific compliance requirements. IT teams are advised to establish a staged development setup in each region to facilitate effective and coordinated integration management.

While this blueprint is common in enterprises where IT responsibilities are decentralized by Business Units, it still requires strong central governance to ensure consistency and re-use across company entities.

Companies may choose a Hybrid model, which combines global oversight with support for local compliance and autonomy. For SAP Integration Suite, this approach may involve using global tenants to manage enterprise-wide or cross-BU integrations, while local BU tenants address regional BU-specific integrations. A strong governance model and organizational structure are necessary to support an efficient Hybrid tenant model. SAP Integration Suite includes the Edge Integration Cell (EIC) runtime, which addresses edge or compliance scenarios and can connect to a local BU tenant.

Pros:

  • Meet regional compliance & data residency requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, local banking laws).
  • Improve performance and reduce latency for in-region integrations
  • Enhance resilience with distributed landscapes.

Cons:

  • Requires a strong balance between global and regional governance
  • Requires centralized monitoring across regions.
  • Costs grow with each regional deployment.

While this blueprint is tailored to global enterprises, companies are advised to evaluate the need for such a setup in all regions based on regional requirements.

Stage 5: The Mature Era ‚Äì Governed Multi-Tenant Strategy

Over time, BestRun Corporation achieved Integration setup maturity, with a reliable, enterprise-wide blueprint that brings the best of both worlds together. The model consists of global SAP Integration Suite tenants designed for shared enterprise integrations, regional SAP Integration Suite tenants that address local regulations and optimize latency, and business unit (BU) tenants tailored for customized business entity-relevant processes.

The goal is not to blindly add ‚Äòmore tenants‚Äô, but move to a smarter, governed model that balances autonomy, compliance, and efficiency. To ensure effective management of this setup, robust governance measures have been implemented. These include automated transport pipelines, centralized monitoring using SAP Cloud ALM, consistent security and identity policies, and a documented tenant strategy to ensure coordination across IT teams in the organization.

BestRun also established an Integration Center of Excellence (CoE) to ensure its Integration strategy was not only technically sound but also organizationally sustainable. Acting as both a governance body and innovation driver, the CoE defines the integration blueprints, enforces governance and security standards, creates reusable integration assets, enables regional IT teams through training & best practices, and pilots emerging capabilities like AI-driven integration.

This balance of global oversight with local autonomy positioned SAP Integration Suite as a strategic enabler of business agility and innovation.

Conclusion

Integration setup is not a one-size-fits-all decision. BestRun Corporation‚Äôs story shows that SAP Integration Suite blueprints tend to evolve - from a single-tenant experiment to a governed, multi-tenant, multi-region landscape, as the organization evolves to transform, scale, and globalize.

Ask yourself, which integration blueprint best shows your current state, and which one matches organizational needs:

  • Are you still experimenting in a single tenant?
  • Have you moved into a staged development setup?
  • Are you operating a mature, governed multi-tenant landscape with global reach?

Wherever you are in this evolution, the key is to keep moving forward till you reach the target setup. Every step towards structured tenant management strengthens your ability to deliver reliable, intelligent, and future-proof integration.

With SAP Integration Suite and well-defined integration blueprints, enterprises can shape landscapes that not only support today‚Äôs business processes but also empower tomorrow‚Äôs innovations.
